item.title: Happy Birthday to the Superior Sibling
item.dc:creator: speaker7
item.description: This blog post is dedicated to my brother who turns 175 today. I like to make cracks about his age because it’s all I really have up on him, the fact that I’m younger. My brother is smart. I mean he is really, really smart. This is what he looks like: He’s the kind of [...]
item.content:encoded:
This blog post is dedicated to my brother who turns 175 today. I like to make cracks about his age because it’s all I really have up on him, the fact that I’m younger.

My brother is smart. I mean he is really, really smart.

This is what he looks like:

smartypants

He’s the kind of smart that people like Sarah Palin hate. She would say something like “Oh so you’re one of those gotcha elitists who like to smear blood libel in the great liberty bell of Paul Revere’s house.  Your kind is just.. um.. is just reprehendiculous.”

You know how there’s only one tenured college professor job for the thousands of people out there looking? Well my brother got that job. He first book of poetry won some big poetry award. I’m not really up on my knowledge of poetry awards, but I think it was something like the Shel Silverstein Ickle Me Tickle Me Award of Excellence. I, on the otherhand, have this published blog. My blog has 9 readers, and I know or am related to about half of them.

Like I mentioned before, I am younger–way, way younger like a little baby duckling or a Courtney Stodden–so I would inevitably get teachers who already had my brother as their student. It would go something like this:

“Oh! You’re ___’s sister! Well then I expect great things from you.” Whoa…hold on. Let’s not all get crazy here. Let’s just calm the #$@! down for a second. Can I put my pencil case in my desk, please? Can I just do that before we all lose our @$&! minds?

As the school year progressed, and their expectations dropped to the lowest pit of despair, they would occasionally reaffirm my relation to my brother. “You’re not adopted, right?”

So okay I’m not as smart as my brother. He got a 1580 on his SATs. I got a *cough* 990 the first time I took the test, but the next time, I studied my little head off. . . and I got at 990.

When I applied for college, my guidance counselor wrote a recommendation that perfectly encapsulated my experience growing up with a much smarter sibling. This was the first sentence: “As a freshman, [Speaker7] was a shy student in the shadow of her brother who was an exceptional student.” She went on to extol his brilliance and the accomplishments of my parents, “pillars of the community.” It was a nicer way of saying “[Speaker7] is pure crap. Maybe her brother or parents can do her classwork for her?”

For the record, I did actually get accepted into a college. I managed to eke out a living as a reporter covering landfills, wheat festivals and crow invasions, and now write a rarely-read blog. It hasn’t been all rainclouds (see: brother’s shadow).

So Happy Birthday brother! You don’t look a day older than 293!

item.title: I see pictures everywhere…
item.dc:creator: Robin
item.description: I have a bit of a problem, I’ll admit it straight out. If I were in a special meeting I would probably look at the people to my left, my right and across from me and say, “Hi, I’m Robin and I see in pictures.” If I’m driving I have to stop myself from screeching [...]
item.content:encoded:
I have a bit of a problem, I’ll admit it straight out. If I were in a special meeting I would probably look at the people to my left, my right and across from me and say, “Hi, I’m Robin and I see in pictures.” If I’m driving I have to stop myself from screeching to a stop when I see a photo opportunity at the side of the road, or down a side street.When I visit friends I have internal debates with myself about how I shouldn’t let the camera out of its bag.

On Saturday I was on my way to friends in Springs, and I experienced one of those times. I saw a woman cutting long grass right at the side of the main road, her bright jersey in stark contrast to the sepias of the thatch, and almost stopped. While I was still lamenting the fact that I hadn’t, an old stone farmhouse next to a lonely winding road jumped out and said, “photograph me,’ … then, a bit further down the road, the straight lines of a fallow field screamed out at me to stop… But I didn’t.

But then I passed a vibrant, noisy motocross track and my hands involuntarily pulled the steering wheel off to the side. These photos, taken with the wrong camera and the wrong lens are the result. The riders weren’t even doing anything phenomenal – they were just practicing and having fun and speaking animatedly to each other afterwards about something they were obviously passionate about.

I love the life and dustiness in the results…

(I know which is my favourite, which is yours?)


Filed under: Photo Feature

item.title: [Norway Trip] Day 2: Oslo –> Bergen
item.dc:creator: nyrahs
item.description: August 11, 2011 On day 2 in Norway, we spent an entire day slowly making our way from Oslo westward to Bergen, the second largest city in Norway. What mattered today was not our final destination, but the journey itself, as we were going to pass by some of the most beautiful sights in Norway—fjords [...]
item.content:encoded:
August 11, 2011

On day 2 in Norway, we spent an entire day slowly making our way from Oslo westward to Bergen, the second largest city in Norway. What mattered today was not our final destination, but the journey itself, as we were going to pass by some of the most beautiful sights in Norway—fjords (valleys carved by glacial activity), mountains, glaciers, lakes, waterfalls and forests. We would set out from Oslo at 8:11 a.m. and arrive in Bergen at 8:35 p.m., a full twelve hours later. It is possible to take a direct train to Bergen from Oslo, which is much faster, but that way you’d miss out on most of the beautiful spots, as they can only be accessed via the Flåm Railway, boat and bus. To make things as hassle-free as possible, I’d bought the “Norway in a Nutshell” package online, which included all the different tickets, so that we wouldn’t have to scramble at the last minute. It was well worth it. The entire journey went pretty smoothly, from Oslo to Myrdal (by train), from Myrdal to Flåm (via Flåmsbana, the Flåm Railway, which has the steepest unassisted railway climb in the world and the most breathtaking views), from Flåm to Gudvangen (a 2-hour boat ride taking us through the Sognefjord), from Gudvangen to Voss (by bus), and finally from Voss to Bergen (by regular train).


8 o’clock in the morning, waiting for the train in Oslo Central Station. I’d woken up with some serious back pain, so at this point I could hardly stand. Luckily the Anker Hotel that we stayed at was right across the street from a hospital with a pharmacy that was open that early, so MT had run out to get me some panadol. Still, I was pretty much demobilized and in a lot of pain all day. I had never been in so much pain my whole life. It took a lot of will power to put on a normal face, enjoy the amazing scenery, and just get through the day.

The scenery was indeed amazing. I don’t have the appropriate words to describe it. Everything was beautiful. I was especially excited to see the glaciers and glacial landscapes, because growing up I’d only ever seen pictures of them in my geography textbooks and they’d always seemed so abstract, belonging to a distant land of snow and ice, but now there they were, right in front of my eyes. Traveling is really the best education you can ever have.

Kjosfossen waterfall (below), one of the stops along the Flåm Line.

You can tell it’s a major tourist attraction when they have ballet students dressing up as seductive creatures from Scandinavian folklore dancing to music played from speakers embedded somewhere. But it was a very nice waterfall. I’m glad I hobbled off the train to look at it despite my excruciating back pain (at the insistence of a very enthusiastic Norwegian guy). This is probably the only time I’ll ever see it in person.

And then we arrived in Flåm, where we boarded the boat that would take us to Gudvangen via the Sognefjord, the largest fjord in Norway and the second deepest and third longest fjord in the world. According to Wikipedia, “Gudvangen is situated by the Nærøyfjord, a branch of the Sognefjord particularly noted for its unspoiled nature and dramatic scenery, and only 300 meters across at its narrowest point. The Nærøyfjord is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.”

We were very lucky that it was such a sunny day. The sky was so blue and clear, as was the water reflecting the majestic mountains surrounding us.

You really have to be there in person to experience the magnificence of the whole landscape.

After landing in Gudvangen, we boarded a bus to Voss, which took us through some nice scenery and steep mountain roads with hairpin bends.

From Voss, we took a train to Bergen, and I was so happy that I had the foresight to book a hotel close to Bergen Railway Station because by then my back was killing me. The panadol pills that I had been taking throughout the day had lost their effectiveness  and the pain was making it difficult to breathe or talk. I’d hardly been able to eat anything all day, and whatever I ate was puked back out. But at least I had made it from Oslo to Bergen. This morning I thought I might have to be hauled off to a hospital somewhere midway, but in the end I did survive the 12-hour journey. There is nothing sweeter than finally seeing our hotel room and laying myself down on the bed at that point. I had no idea whether I would be able to get up again anytime soon. It would be a shame to miss Bergen after all that effort put into getting there, but we’ll just have to wait and see.

item.title: A Few Guilty Pleasures That Might Make Me Lose My Man Card
item.dc:creator: robwalls
item.description: I live in a woman’s world (at least at home I do). I am the only man in my house. Between my wife Court, my daughters Larkin and Lorelei and our dog Sophie I guess I am lucky that our house hasn’t been completely taken over by flowers and the color pink. I have to [...]
item.content:encoded:
I live in a woman’s world (at least at home I do). I am the only man in my house. Between my wife Court, my daughters Larkin and Lorelei and our dog Sophie I guess I am lucky that our house hasn’t been completely taken over by flowers and the color pink. I have to admit, though, there are a lot of benefits. I have been exposed to things that I am sure I would have never experienced if I were living in a house full of guys like I did growing up (minus my mom).

I am potentially subjecting myself to a lot of ridicule because of what I am getting ready to admit but I have found that there are a lot of things that I have come to appreciate because of the women in my life that might make you question my masculinity. Here are a few guilty pleasures that could potentially make me lose my man card:

1. The Bachelor Pad- I can’t believe I am saying this but my wife has got me completely hooked on this show. I know it’s staged and I know that the target market is women but I would be lying if I said that I don’t like it. Just as a disclaimer, I want to make it clear that I do not like the Bachelor or the Bachelorette. I think I can watch the Bachelor Pad because there is some strategy to it.

2. Pretty Little Liars- TV Show, I don’t know that I can really justify this one. I just like it. That’s all.

3. The Pioneer Woman- I have started getting into cooking and she has a lot of good recipes. She is also an amazing photographer. 

The way I see it, my ability to admit to these guilty pleasures just shows that I am confident in my manhood and I don’t need to be watching football and yelling at the tv to prove it (although I will be doing that this weekend when Ohio State is playing).

What are some of your guilty pleasures that you are willing to admit?

item.title: A Few Photos From ScotiaBank Toronto BuskerFest 2011
item.dc:creator: lightmonkeyphotography
item.description: For the past 7 years we have spent the last weekend of August shooting the Toronto Buskerfest, sponsored by ScotiaBank. This year the festival seemed bigger than ever with crowds of spectators and over 100 performers out on the pitches giving their best in support of Epilepsy Toronto. In additional to the usual shots of [...]
item.content:encoded:
For the past 7 years we have spent the last weekend of August shooting the Toronto Buskerfest, sponsored by ScotiaBank. This year the festival seemed bigger than ever with crowds of spectators and over 100 performers out on the pitches giving their best in support of Epilepsy Toronto.

In additional to the usual shots of the performers in action, we also set up a make-shift studio in the performer’s greenroom hoping to capture something unique from each performer and give recognition to all of the crew members who put so much of their time and effort into making this festival the largest of it’s kind in North America. Above are a few shots from the street and the studio, more will follow in the days to come as we sort through the thousands of shots the weekend provided.

For those of you who missed our portrait series from last year you can see it here. And once again, our thanks to everyone who stood before our cameras, you allowed us to give a collective face to a festival.

item.title: Autumn on my Mind
item.dc:creator: eyeitryit
item.description: My mom is in town for the weekend and of course, what are we going to do? SHOP! Today, my mom and I went all sorts of shopping; grocery shopping, home cleaning product shopping, and course clothes shopping! Perhaps its because I go to fashion school, or maybe its that I live with my style-guru [...]
item.content:encoded:
My mom is in town for the weekend and of course, what are we going to do? SHOP! Today, my mom and I went all sorts of shopping; grocery shopping, home cleaning product shopping, and course clothes shopping! Perhaps its because I go to fashion school, or maybe its that I live with my style-guru sister, Chriselle, and she is always a few seasons ahead of the current fashion trends, but I am always shopping for with the the next season in mind. In January, I’m already shopping for spring maxi dresses and wedge sandals. In August (right now), I’m shopping for the autumn/winter season and have my eye out for wool dresses, and long trench coats. Because I have autumn on my mind, this roasted, caramelly, sticky, roasted, savory, sweet, and dark vegetable dish is perfect. Acorn squash is one of the easiest vegetable sides you could make for a dinner party and make it look and taste like a dish from Master Chef (I’m obsessed with the reality competition cooking show). And it looks so pretty on the plate with the bright orange and green contrasting colors. This is a perfect appetizer dish for those holiday parties, a healthy vegetarian dinner dish for those cold nights,  and its even fitting for an after supper dessert!        

Autumn Roasted Acorn Squash

Ingredients:

  • 1 acorn squash (cut in half, and seeded)
  • 2 tbsp brown sugar
  • 1 tbsp vegan butter (I used Earth Balance)
  • 1 1.2 tbsp organic maple syrup
  • Pinch of salt (to taste)
  • Ground black pepper (to taste)

Directions:

  • Preheat oven to 350 degrees.
  • Place both halves of the squash on a lined baking pan (cut side down).
  • Bake for ~30 minutes.
  • Remove from oven. Turn the squash over and rub the inside of the squash with the brown sugar/butter mixture and put it in the oven again, cut side up this time.
  • Bake for another 20 minutes. Remove from oven and oven and eat out of the halved acorn squash or cut it into slices!

Filed under: Appetizers, Dessert, Dinner, Lunch/Light Dinner, Vegan Tagged: squash, Vegan

item.title: I Like My Bike
item.dc:creator: Aimee @ everydayepistle.com
item.description: My friend Corey turned 40 this year and announced he would now be living as if he were half his age. I promptly decided to adopt this philosophy. Of course there are many things I can’t do now that I could do when I was 20. Well, I may still be able to do them. [...]
item.content:encoded:
Cindy II (not to be confused with my homegirl, the unflappable Cyndi Tew)

My friend Corey turned 40 this year and announced he would now be living as if he were half his age. I promptly decided to adopt this philosophy.

Of course there are many things I can’t do now that I could do when I was 20.

Well, I may still be able to do them. But just because I can, doesn’t mean I should.

Staying up past a reasonable bedtime? No longer a good idea. Drinking more than an occasional glass of wine? Not good either. Eating half a five-dollar pizza all by myself? No.

There are other things though. Things I haven’t done for many years that are good for me. Enter Cindy.

Cindy was my first bike, complete with a banana seat and streamers on the handle bars. A horse was not in the cards, but I could name a bike just as well.

I received Cindy way before I was 20. Probably around age five or six. I’ll never forget learning to ride that bike. How wonderful it felt to be free and go fast.

Somewhere in the murky years of high school, I gave up bike riding. And skating. And swimming. Fun things I once enjoyed. Why do we do that?

fun on ice...

Then a couple years ago, I decided to take my little boy skating at Steinberg Ice Rink in Forest Park. It was a perfect December day. He was too young to be on the ice for very long. I, however, had a ball.

We went skating again this past winter. He got the hang of balancing and moving at the same time. But all he really wanted to do was spin around in circles and fall and laugh.

We go swimming too. Although momma doesn’t always let her hair get wet, the water is like a long-lost friend.

...and in water

When my husband received a reward certificate with an option to redeem for a bike, I lobbied. I had my eye on a sleek, expensive model at Big Shark Bicycle Company in the Loop. But a free bike? We had nothing to lose.

My son was as excited as I was when the bike arrived in a big box last week. We unpacked it, all shiny and purple.

He helped my husband put it together. Insists I wear my helmet as we ride around the neighborhood.

When I’m with him, we go slowly. He’s still learning. When I’m alone, I fly.

Someday I hope he’ll fly beside me and know what I remember. How wonderful it feels to be free and go fast.

good night, sweetheart!

So, I’m all for just going ahead and having a good time—the best possible. The only earthly good men and women can look forward to is to eat and drink well and have a good time—compensation for the struggle for survival these few years God gives us on earth. Ecclesiastes 8:15 The Message

Be free, go fast, and meet me back here next week!

How could I forget to mention the bicycle is a good invention?


Filed under: life and death, motherhood, writing Tagged: Bicycle Song, biking, fun, life, Red Hot Chili Peppers, skating, swimming

item.title: Attack of the killer bees and backhanded compliments – My week condensed
item.dc:creator: joehoover
item.description: 1) At the dawning of a new week I was faced with a conundrum, clear signs that this week was about to test my resolve and my whole ethics system.   Sleepy eyed I moved to board the train as it pulled into Camden Road station and I spied a wasp on the back of a man’s [...]
